repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Roads Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance, and Freetown Infrastructure Rehabilitation Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit downgrades the Implementation
            Completion Report (ICR) rating of satisfactory project
            outcomes to moderately satisfactory for both the Roads
            Rehabilitation and Maintenance (RRMP), and the Freetown
            Infrastructure Rehabilitation (FIRP) Projects; concurs on a
            likely sustainability for the RRMP, but downgrades the FIRP
            sustainability to unlikely; and, downgrades the RRMP
            institutional development impact to substantial, yet concurs
            with the FIRP modest rating, and with both satisfactory
            performance ratings by the Bank and Borrower. The experience
            of these two operations convey the following. Projects
            implemented in countries with an ongoing conflict, should be
            continually monitored to identify, and assess the conflict
            risk to the projects. First, under continuing high risk
            conditions, thus project implementation likely to prove
            counterproductive, by exposing the Bank and Borrower to
            compensation and other claims, the Bank might consider
            disengagement until the environment improves. Second, upon
            resuming project implementation following a substantial
            period of inactivity due to conflict, technical and
            financial audits should be carried out to reassess
            priorities for action, as well as, and any remedial measures
            needed to secure completed activities. Third, when a country
            is in, or emerging from conflict, the Bank may need to adopt
            a more flexible approach to borrower compliance with
            reform-related loan covenants. A realistic timeframe should
            be agreed when attempting to introduce unpopular reforms in
            the context of violence, and social instability.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Roads Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory,
            sustainability likely, and institutional development impacts
            high. Lessons drawn from the project implementation suggest
            that, in spite of difficult conflict situations, such as the
            case in Sierra Leone, motivated institutions, and staff do
            succeed in creating the structure to achieve project
            objectives, as illustrated by the benefit of the "green
            field" approach, where new institutions were firmly
            established. It is particularly important to note that, in
            order to consolidate progress in institutional development
            (to be strengthened by additional funding for road
            rehabilitation, and maintenance as needed), the
            implementation of a follow-up project - Transport Sector
            Project - became paramount, given the context of the country
            at that time. However, the Sierra Leone Roads Authority
            (SLRA) Act separating the Road Fund from the Ministry of
            Works, though an improvement over previous arrangements,
            would have better improved transparency, and accountability,
            had the Road Fund's resource mobilization been
            separated from the SLRA operations. The report also
            reinforces that in recurrent civil strife, contracts should
            be as small as possible to avoid lengthy implementation time
            between bidding, and works completion.

18156910.theme: Other rural development,Participation and civic engagement,Infrastructure services for private sector development
18156910.majtheme: Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Road Rehabilitation and
            Maintenance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the project is to
            remove physical bottlenecks in the country's transport
            network through a sustainable road rehabilitation and
            maintenance program, and to build institutional capacity to
            better plan, manage and maintain roads and other transport
            facilities.  The project supports:  (a) a four year time
            slice consisting of the first phase of a seven year program
            for road network rehabilitation and maintenance; (b) the
            establishment and strengthening of the Sierra Leone Roads
            Authority to manage the road network; (c) training and other
            support to strengthen small domestic contractors including
            training in labor-intensive methods; (d) promotion of
            non-motorized transport in rural areas to improve transport
            services to the poor and assistance to nongovernmental
            organizations for this purpose; and (e) strengthening
            transport sector planning.
